title: Form Uses GET Method (Unspecified Default) - Data Exposed in URL
description:
The contact form in the HTML does not specify an HTTP method, which defaults to GET in HTML forms per W3C specification. Additionally, the form is missing an action attribute, so it would submit to the current page (http://localhost:8080/).

When a form uses the GET method, all form data is appended to the URL as query parameters, making the data visible in multiple locations including:
1. Browser address bar
2. Browser history and cache
3. Server access logs
4. Proxy and CDN logs
5. HTTP Referrer headers sent to other sites
6. Network traffic (in plaintext if HTTP)

The form contains fields with personally identifiable information:
- name (personal information)
- email (personal information, used for account targeting)
- message (potentially sensitive user information)

The HTML form element lacks the method attribute: `<form id="contact-form" class="mx-auto" style="max-width: 600px;">` - This defaults to GET per HTML specifications, causing all subsequent form submissions to expose data in the URL query string.
impact:
If this form were connected to a backend endpoint, all user input would be exposed in URLs, compromising user privacy:
1. Personal information (name, email, message) would be visible in URLs
2. Browser history would persistently store all submitted form data
3. Server access logs would record all query parameters for each form submission
4. Proxy servers and CDNs would see and potentially log all form data
5. Referrer headers sent to external sites might include sensitive user information
6. Form data could be cached by browsers and intermediaries
7. URL length restrictions (2048-2083 characters) would limit form data size
8. Compliance violations with data protection regulations (GDPR, CCPA, etc.)
evidence:
POC execution confirmed:
- Contact form found in HTML response
- Form element verified to lack method attribute: `<form id="contact-form" ...>` (no method specified)
- Form field names extracted: name, email, message
- All fields contain sensitive personal data

Example exposure: http://localhost:8080/?name=John%20Doe&email=john.doe@example.com&message=I%20need%20your%20services%20urgently

This data would be visible in:
1. Browser address bar: http://localhost:8080/?name=John%20Doe&email=john.doe@example.com&message=...
2. Browser history files containing full URL with parameters
3. Server access logs: GET /?name=John%20Doe&email=john.doe@example.com&message=... HTTP/1.1
4. HTTP Referrer headers if user navigates away
5. Proxy/CDN logs of all intermediate infrastructure

POC execution output shows the vulnerability chain clearly demonstrating multiple exposure points.
